title: The strange, frustrating, amazing truth about ADHD and goals
author: Unknown
content_text: Photo by Markus Winkler on Unsplash I used to think I was lazy. Unmotivated. Broken maybe… A guy called Mike Ogier talked me through one to one in one of the first jobs i had over 30 years ago. It worked for a few weeks but …. And several other supervisors including Andy Harrington emphasise the importance of Goals. Skip 30 years I realized my brain wasn’t wired for traditional goals. It was wired for chaos, curiosity... and caffeine. Here’s what I learned about goal setting when you live with ADHD. There’s this weird moment that hits me every January. Everyone’s out here with their vision boards and ten-step plans. And I’m just over here… trying to remember where I left my phone. Or my coffee. Or both. I used to write down big goals. You know the kind: “I’m gonna write a book.” “I’m gonna lose 10 pounds.” “I’ll finally start that podcast.” Felt great for about 10 minutes. Then... poof. Gone. Forgotten. Overwhelmed. Burnt out. Sometimes all at once. Let’s talk about why ADHD messes with your goals First thing you gotta know... ADHD isn’t about not trying hard enough. It’s a different operating system. Neurotypicals set goals like they're climbing a ladder. Step by step. One rung at a time. Us? We’re jumping off trampolines blindfolded hoping to land on a moving platform. It’s not linear. It’s emotional. It’s chaotic. And it’s deeply personal. These are the goal-setting traps I fell into (over and over again) I set goals that sounded good ... not ones I actually cared about I planned for “ideal me”... not real messy exhausted me I relied on discipline... instead of designing systems I got obsessed with outcomes... and forgot to enjoy the process I judged myself by other people’s timelines... ouch I once spent three weeks building a productivity tracker. Color-coded, daily habits, little dopamine hits. Guess how long I used it? Two days. So what actually works? Not a list of hacks. Not another planner. Here’s what finally started working for me: 1. I set themes instead of goals Instead of “write 3 blog posts a week,” I picked a theme like create consistently . Gave me space to explore. No pressure. 2. I used time blindness to my advantage Deadlines feel fake? Cool. I made artificial urgency my best friend. I set tiny 10-minute timers. Sprint. Stop. Celebrate. 3. I chased dopamine the right way No more boring to-do lists. I gamified everything. Points for sending emails. Rewards for staying off TikTok. I even named my to-do list “Boss Battle.” It sounds dumb. But it works. 4. I quit goals that weren’t mine Biggest win ever. Turns out, I didn’t really want to run a marathon. I wanted to prove something. I stopped chasing goals that weren’t me. If you feel like you're failing... you're not You're not lazy. You're not broken. You're not doomed to live in the land of unfinished ideas. You just need goals that fit your brain.
